questions.question_text:
A project manager is assigned to a new project that will launch the digital version of a current product. Even though the product is well known, the vision for its digital version is not clear to the stakeholders.
What should the project manager do to increase value delivery?

choices.C: Work with the team on the definition of a minimum viable product (MVP) and present it to the stakeholders
choices.B: Create a visual task board with all of the relevant stakeholders to support backlog prioritization
choices.D: Use spikes to dig deeper into the technical challenges of the new product, thus reducing the technical risk
choices.A: Gather the team to create a comprehensive product roadmap but only commit to requirements for the next quarter

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option C is the most suitable choice in this scenario as it emphasizes value delivery through iterative development and stakeholder involvement. Creating an MVP helps the team stay focused on the most important aspects of the product, reduces the risk of building unnecessary features, and ensures that the initial version aligns with stakeholders' expectations.

Correct answer is C.

B cannot be correct. Why? Because, how can stakeholders help with prioritization when they don't even understand the existence of the project (the vision). And plus, backlog prioritization is for the Product Owner, the project team and maybe a few SMEs (only if required). Including all of the stakeholders in backlog refinement is just going to be too many conflicts and extra noise, resulting in decisions not being made on time, specially when stakeholders do not understand the project/product vision.

Creating a definition of the MVP will help the stakeholders see, feel, understand and provide feedback at a very early stage rather than waiting for the end of the project to understand or realize the benefits, and by then maybe it is already too late. You would lose support of many of your key stakeholders.

What should the project manager do?

discussion.content:

The answer is definitely C.
As the definition of PMP.
"Lessons learned" is a work review recorded by those who participated in the "project" work after the work is completed. "lessons learned" mainly records the reasons for the success of the work and the reasons for the failure.
"History information" is also called history records. "History information" records quantitative data after the completion of various project work, including the actual construction period, actual cost used, and the actual number of resources used after the work is completed.
If you want to choose D

Benchmarking: Similar projects serve as benchmarks, allowing the project manager to make more realistic and evidence-based cost estimates.

While involving the client representative, including contingency, and reviewing lessons learned are important aspects of project planning, reviewing completion costs from similar projects is the most direct way to estimate costs for the business case.
